description:
Venezuela announced on March 16th an extension of the lockdown (dubbed as social quarantine) to the entire country, comprising all remaining states, starting on March 17th at 5AM until further notice. Essential business workers as well as law enforcement and health personnel are exempted. UPDATE: Venezuela's president Maduro announced on April 24th a phase-out measure. On Sunday 4/26, from 9am to 6pm, children and young people can leave their homes and go outside. On April 27, between 10am and 2pm, people of 65 and older than go up to one block away from their homes. This will take place in all municipalities except Nueva Esparta. 
The initial lockdown was a complete lockdown for the population, whereas now certain demographic groups are allowed to leave their houses during a certain time frame for one day.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
In the context of Venezuela's new model dubbed as "dynamic flexibility" that was announced by president on May 30th and will start on June 1st, a large share of the nationwide population will be able to go outside their their homes during specific times of the day, thus  lockdown restrictions are being eased; excepting the border municipalities that will maintain their respective curfews.
Venezuelan model is dubbed as 5 x 10: 5 days of flexibilization and 10 consecutive days of social quarantine.

description:
In the context of Venezuela's new model dubbed as "dynamic flexibility" that was announced by president on May 30th and will start on June 1st, a large share of the nationwide population will be able to go outside their their homes during specific times of the day, thus  lockdown restrictions are being eased; excepting the border municipalities that will maintain their respective curfews.
Venezuelan model is dubbed as 5 x 10: 5 days of flexibilization and 10 consecutive days of social quarantine. It has been changed to a 7+7 model. It has been eased to 7 days of relaxation and a following 7 days of lockdown.

description: Starting from July 13, three levels of flexibility will come into effect in Venezuela under the 7+7 scheme. Under the first level will be Zulia, all border municipalities, El Vigía in Mérida, and Cumaná in Sucre. At the second level, in partial flexibility with 10 sectors open are Carabobo, Trujillo, Mérida (except El Vigía), Táchira (except border municipalities), Apure (except border municipalities), Bolívar (except Santa Elena de Uairén), Aragua, Capital District, Miranda, Sucre, Falcón, Anzoátegui, and Yaracuy. Amazonas, Barinas, Cojedes, Delta Amacuro, Guárico, Lara, Monagas, Nueva Esparta, Portuguesa and La Guairá will be in expanded flexibility with 24 sectors open.

description: Venezuela’s 7+7 plan is still in effect but has begun Phase 2, allowing all 24 economic sectors to reopen, on August 10. Additional states are being added to Phase 1 of the flexibilization policy including Caracas (center-north), Miranda (center-north), Zulia (north-west), La Guaira (center-north), Sucre (northeast), Bolívar (south), and Táchira (west). Other municipalities bordering Columbia are still in quarantine. UPDATE: This phase of lockdown is ending on September 28th as Venezuela enters the 7+7 Plus plan.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units (other than provincial or city level units) within one or more countries
target_other: Caracas (center-north); Miranda (center-north); Zulia (north-west); La Guaira (center-north); Sucre (northeast); Bolívar (south); Táchira (west)

description: On August 10, the 7 + 7 scheme will be applied in two levels of flexibility. In partial flexibility with 10 sectors opened will be Capital District, Miranda, Zulia, La Guairá, Sucre, Bolivar, and Táchira. In expanded flexibility with 24 sectors opened will be Lara, Merida, Trujillo, Barinas, Guárico, Portuguesa, Cojedes, Falcon, Monagas, Anzoátegui, Aragua, Carabobo, Nueva Esparta, Amazonas, Delta Amacuro, and Apure. All border municipalities are exempt and will remain in lockdown. UPDATE: On August 24, more Venezuelan states have been added to Phase 2.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: Venezeula's 7+7 plan is still in effect. 21 states of the country have been moved to Phase 2, which reopens all 24 economic sectors, including Mérida, Monagas, Trujillo, Carabobo, Yaracuy, Guárico, Portuguesa, Cojedes, Amazonas, Sucre, Nueva Esparta, Anzoátegui, Barinas, Aragua, Lara, Delta Amacuro, Falcón, as well as, Zulia, Bolívar, Táchira, Apure (excluding the bordering municipalities). Caracas, La Guaira and Miranda are still under Phase 1 – partial flexibility.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On August 3, President Maduro of Venezuela instructed the Presidential Commission for the Prevention, Attention, and Control of COVID-19 to attend to three tasks: implementing effective measures for migrants entering through legal border crossings, enforcing rules of radical quarantine to stop the spread of COVID-19, and taking a greater effort in reversing moderate and serious cases to decrease the death toll.

description:
On March 13, the Venezuelan government passed quarantine guidelines: Patients suspected of having contracted the coronavirus that causes COVID-19, as well as those in whom such a diagnosis has been confirmed by being positive according to any of the duly certified tests for the detection of COVID-I9 or any of its strains will remain in quarantine and in isolation until it is verified by said test that they no longer represent a risk for the spread of the virus, even when they present mild symptoms.
People who have been exposed to patients suspected or confirmed to have contracted the coronavirus that causes COVID-19 must also remain in quarantine or isolation.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

description: On March 13, 2020, the government of Venezuela announced that everyone who had direct contact with the patient infected or suspected of having contracted the virus; visited patients who are sick or suspected of be; having stayed in the same environment with sick patients, or suspected of being sick, whether during work, academic, professional activities or social relationships of any kind; had traveled in any type of ship, aircraft or vehicle with an affected or suspected patient; had lived in the same property with a patient with COVID-19 in the 14 days after the appearance of their first symptoms; had direct contact with the persons indicated in some of the preceding numerals will be considered as  a possible carrier of COVID-19 by the Ministry of  of Health of Venezuela. Also, the people indicated above will remain in quarantine for a period of two (2) weeks.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The Venezuelan authorities have announced the implementation of a  social and collective quarantine  from March 17, 2020 (5 am - local time) throughout the territory. This measure limits travel to what is strictly necessary, namely food purchases or those related to medical care. To prevent further spread of the virus, all activities will be suspended except for food, health, transport, and security services.

From March 18, Caracas' metro and other rail systems will close and only provide services for workers from prioritized sectors, such as food, health, transport, media, and public services. Such individuals will be required to show identification prior to taking public transport.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As reported on April 6, 2020, in Venezuela, migrants who enter from Cúcuta (Bolivia) into the state of Táchira through the Simón Bolívar International Bridge must take blood antibody tests and quarantine for at least 14 days despite the results of their COVID-test.

description: On June 1, 10 economic sectors are reopening in Venezuela except in border municipalities or areas under curfew. While it began under a 5x10 model: 5 days of flexibilization, followed by 10 days of lockdown, on June 5, that model was changed to a 7x7 model. The details regarding which sectors are allowed to open remain unchanged. The 10 sectors are transportation, banking, construction, hardware, medical and dental offices, hairdressers, textile and footwear, the industry of chemical raw materials, mechanical parts and auto parts, personalized services

description:
The Venezuelan Institution for regulating the Banking sector (SUDEBAN) decreed the nationwide suspension of banking activities on March 15th, thus imposing a restriction on private and public banking business activities starting from March 16th. 
This measure has been partly lifted, as banking activities are resumed for certain hours of the day, as part of the nationwide "dynamic flexibility" phase-out model. UPDATE: The original policy decreed to suspend all banking activities. They have been resumed starting from June 1st under a restriction of working hours.

description: On June 15, 14 additional economic sectors will open under the 7x7 plan. The sectors reopening are car wash, optical, electronic repairs, marketing of textile, industry and marketing of stationery, ice cream parlors and cafes, laundries, manufacture of electronic equipment, parcel services, registries and notaries, sports events (no public present) and gyms, veterinary, drive-ins, and shopping centers. This is in addition to the previous 10 sectors from the first phase: banking agencies, construction, hardware, medical and dental offices, hairdressers, textile and footwear industry, industry sector of chemical raw materials, mechanical parts, personalized services, and transportation.

description: On June 15, 14 additional economic sectors will open under the 7x7 plan. The sectors reopening are car wash, optical, electronic repairs, marketing of textile, industry and marketing of stationery, ice cream parlors and cafes, laundries, manufacture of electronic equipment, parcel services, registries and notaries, sports events (no public present) and gyms, veterinary, drive-ins, and shopping centers. This is in addition to the previous 10 sectors from the first phase: banking agencies, construction, hardware, medical and dental offices, hairdressers, textile and footwear industry, industry sector of chemical raw materials, mechanical parts, personalized services, and transportation. UPDATE: From July 13, the states of Venezuela will enter new phases of flexibility. States with higher contagion levels will be placed in radical quarantine, while others will be in partial or expanded flexibility.

States with higher contagion levels will be placed in radical quarantine, while others will be in partial or expanded flexibility.

description: In Venezuela, from September 7 - 13, all 23 states plus the Capital District, except for border municipalities, will adopt the wide flexibility level with 24 economic sectors opening. The sectors are construction, hardware, chemical raw materials, banking agencies, transportation, hairdressers, mechanical workshops and auto parts, medical, dental and veterinary offices, textile industry and personalized services, car washes, opticians, electronic repairs, shoe and textile shops, bookstores and stationeries, cafeterias and ice cream parlors, laundry and dry cleaning, manufacture of electronic equipment, parcel services, registries and notaries, gyms, drive-ins and shopping centers. This policy will be under the 7x7 model, meaning that restrictions are eased for 7 days, followed by a lockdown for 7 days. UPDATE: From October 5 to October 11, all states in Venezuela, except for border municipalities, will enter into a week of wide flexibility under the fifth phase of the 7+7 Plus plan.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: From October 19 to 25, President Maduro announced that, under the 7+7 Plan, businesses associated with furniture stores, piñatería, hardware stores, confectioneries, jewelry stores, pawnshops, perfume stores, florists, nurseries, liquor stores, restaurants, coffee shops, and ice cream parlors will reopen. The tourism and hotel sector will also resume commercial activities, including inns, hotels, beaches, liquor stores, restaurants, coffee shops, ice cream parlors, beaches and spas, clubs, theme parks, cable cars, and drive-ins. This is in addition to the 24 economic sectors from earlier weeks as well as some state institutions.

description: On March 18, in order to guarantee food to the Venezuelan people, President Maduro has begun a national deployment of los Comité Local de Abastecimiento y Producción (CLAP) to distribute food under the house-to-house delivery modality. The feeding of the people will in in coordination with CLAP and the National Armed Forces (Fuerza Armada Nacional Bolivariana or FANB) and under the Ministerio del Poder Popular para la Alimentación. UPDATE: On March 22, the Venezuelan government ratified an investment in food measure through the Centralized Public Procurement Plan, allowing the distribution of 7 million CLAP until August.

description: On June 1, 10 economic sectors are reopening in Venezuela except in border municipalities or areas under curfew. While it began under a 5x10 model: 5 days of flexibilization, followed by 10 days of lockdown, on June 5, that model was changed to a 7x7 model. The details regarding which sectors are allowed to open remain unchanged. The 10 sectors are transportation, banking, construction, hardware, medical and dental offices, hairdressers, textile and footwear, the industry of chemical raw materials, mechanical parts and auto parts, personalized services

description: On June 15, 14 additional economic sectors will open under the 7x7 plan. The sectors reopening are car wash, optical, electronic repairs, marketing of textile, industry and marketing of stationery, ice cream parlors and cafes, laundries, manufacture of electronic equipment, parcel services, registries and notaries, sports events (no public present) and gyms, veterinary, drive-ins, and shopping centers. This is in addition to the previous 10 sectors from the first phase: banking agencies, construction, hardware, medical and dental offices, hairdressers, textile and footwear industry, industry sector of chemical raw materials, mechanical parts, personalized services, and transportation. UPDATE: From July 13, the states of Venezuela will enter new phases of flexibility. States with higher contagion levels will be placed in radical quarantine, while others will be in partial or expanded flexibility.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

This is in addition to the previous 10 sectors from the first phase: banking agencies, construction, hardware, medical and dental offices, hairdressers, textile and footwear industry, industry sector of chemical raw materials, mechanical parts, personalized services, and transportation. UPDATE: From July 13, the states of Venezuela will enter new phases of flexibility. States with higher contagion levels will be placed in radical quarantine, while others will be in partial or expanded flexibility.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: In Venezuela, from July 27 to August 2, the states of Carabobo, Aragua, Falcon, Anzoátegui, Yaracuy, Nueva Esparta, Monagas, Merida, and Lara will be in partial flexibility (Level 2). 10 sectors will be authorized to operate: construction, hardware, chemical raw material, transportation, banking, hairdressers, mechanical workshops, medical and dental offices, textile and footwear, and personalized plumbing.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Personal Grooming Businesses (e.g. hair salons)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: In Venezuela, from July 27 to August 2, the states of Amazonas, Barinas, Cojedes, Delta Amacuro, Guárico, Portuguesa, Trujillo, and Apure (except border municipalities) will be in expanded flexibility (Level 3). 24 sectors will be open: car washes, optics, electronic repairs, textile, footwear and repair retailers, paper marketing and bookstores, ice cream parlors and cafeterias that operate only at home, laundries and dry cleaners, manufacture and assembly of electronic equipment, parcel services, registries and notaries, sporting events without public and gyms, veterinarians, drive-in movies, and shopping centers. In total, 62 sectors of the national economic life will be active, but it is unspecified as to which.

description: In Venezuela, from September 7 - 13, all 23 states plus the Capital District, except for border municipalities, will adopt the wide flexibility level with 24 economic sectors opening. The sectors are construction, hardware, chemical raw materials, banking agencies, transportation, hairdressers, mechanical workshops and auto parts, medical, dental and veterinary offices, textile industry and personalized services, car washes, opticians, electronic repairs, shoe and textile shops, bookstores and stationeries, cafeterias and ice cream parlors, laundry and dry cleaning, manufacture of electronic equipment, parcel services, registries and notaries, gyms, drive-ins and shopping centers. This policy will be under the 7x7 model, meaning that restrictions are eased for 7 days, followed by a lockdown for 7 days.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Shopping Centers

The sectors are construction, hardware, chemical raw materials, banking agencies, transportation, hairdressers, mechanical workshops and auto parts, medical, dental and veterinary offices, textile industry and personalized services, car washes, opticians, electronic repairs, shoe and textile shops, bookstores and stationeries, cafeterias and ice cream parlors, laundry and dry cleaning, manufacture of electronic equipment, parcel services, registries and notaries, gyms, drive-ins and shopping centers. This policy will be under the 7x7 model, meaning that restrictions are eased for 7 days, followed by a lockdown for 7 days.

The sectors are construction, hardware, chemical raw materials, banking agencies, transportation, hairdressers, mechanical workshops and auto parts, medical, dental and veterinary offices, textile industry and personalized services, car washes, opticians, electronic repairs, shoe and textile shops, bookstores and stationeries, cafeterias and ice cream parlors, laundry and dry cleaning, manufacture of electronic equipment, parcel services, registries and notaries, gyms, drive-ins and shopping centers. This policy will be under the 7x7 model, meaning that restrictions are eased for 7 days, followed by a lockdown for 7 days. UPDATE: From October 5 to October 11, all states in Venezuela, except for border municipalities, will enter into a week of wide flexibility under the fifth phase of the 7+7 Plus plan.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Construction
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: From October 19 to 25, President Maduro announced that, under the 7+7 Plan, businesses associated with furniture stores, piñatería, hardware stores, confectioneries, jewelry stores, pawnshops, perfume stores, florists, nurseries, liquor stores, restaurants, coffee shops, and ice cream parlors will reopen. The tourism and hotel sector will also resume commercial activities, including inns, hotels, beaches, liquor stores, restaurants, coffee shops, ice cream parlors, beaches and spas, clubs, theme parks, cable cars, and drive-ins. This is in addition to the 24 economic sectors from earlier weeks as well as some state institutions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Retail Businesses

UPDATE: On February 17, President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela announced the extension of the easing of the quarantine until February 21.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Commercial Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From March 15 to March 21, Venezuela entered a week of flexibility, but it will be partial in the Capital Region (Capital District, Miranda, and Vargas states) and in the state of Bolívar. Only 10 sectors will be active in those regions - offices, construction, hardware stores, hairdressers, banks, textiles, mechanical workshops, plumbing, refrigeration services, and transportation.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Personal Grooming Businesses (e.g. hair salons)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
